definitions.definition: easily or clearly heard, seen, felt, etc.

examples.text: There was a distinct smell of gas.
His voice was quiet but every word was distinct.

definitions.definition: clearly different or of a different kind

examples.text: The results of the survey fell into two distinct groups.
Jamaican reggae music is quite distinct from North American jazz or blues.
We are talking about rural areas, **as distinct from **major cities.
Political power should be regarded as analytically distinct from economic power.
She was studying lung cancer, as distinct from other types of cancer.
The various dialects are quite distinct from one another.
Manufacturers hope their new products will be sufficiently distinct to command higher prices.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that you think an idea or situation definitely exists and is important

examples.text: Being tall gave Tony a distinct advantage.
I had the distinct impression I was being watched.
A strike is now a distinct possibility.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘differentiated’): from Latin distinctus ‘separated, distinguished’, from the verb distinguere, from dis- ‘apart’ + stinguere ‘put out’.
